question_text: Which philosopher formulated the ontological argument for God's existence in 1078, defining God as 'a being than which no greater can be conceived'?
correct_answer: Anselm of Canterbury, in his work Proslogion
distractors: Thomas Aquinas, in his work Summa Theologica
Augustine of Hippo, in his work City of God
René Descartes, in his work Meditations on First Philosophy

question_text: In classical physics and chemistry, what two fundamental characteristics define matter?
correct_answer: Having mass and occupying space by having volume
distractors: Emitting radiation and generating gravitational wave distortions
Possessing electrical charge and producing magnetic field interactions
Exhibiting wave-particle duality and quantum spin angular momentum

question_text: In the philosophy of mathematics, what position holds that numbers exist as mind-independent abstract entities in a realm separate from the physical world?
correct_answer: Platonism, which asserts numbers are real abstract objects existing independently of human thought
distractors: Formalism, which asserts numbers are syntactic symbols manipulated by explicit formal rules
Nominalism, which asserts numbers are convenient labels for patterns among concrete particulars
Intuitionism, which asserts numbers are mental constructions produced by finite cognitive processes

question_text: What does ontology, as a branch of metaphysics, primarily investigate?
correct_answer: The nature of being, what kinds of entities exist, and their fundamental categories
distractors: The limits of human knowledge, justified belief, and rational epistemic standards
The principles of valid deductive inference and formal logical system construction
The origins of moral value, ethical obligation, and normative behavioral standards

question_text: What is the concept of Laplace's demon meant to illustrate about determinism?
correct_answer: That an intellect knowing all positions and velocities of every particle could perfectly predict the entire future
distractors: That an observer measuring any quantum state inevitably disturbs it and introduces fundamental uncertainty
That a sufficiently powerful computer simulating the universe would require infinite energy to operate
That a being outside of time could freely choose to intervene in any causal sequence at will

question_text: In Aristotle's metaphysics, what is a 'primary substance'?
correct_answer: An individual concrete entity, such as a particular horse, that exists independently and cannot be predicated of anything else
distractors: A universal form, such as the species horse, that exists independently and can be predicated of many individual things
An abstract mathematical object, such as a geometric shape, that exists independently and structures the physical world
A fundamental physical element, such as earth or water, that exists independently and composes all material bodies

question_text: What are the three main philosophical positions regarding the ontological status of properties?
distractors: Empiricism, rationalism, and pragmatism
Monism, dualism, and pluralism
Idealism, materialism, and phenomenalism

question_text: What distinguishes David Lewis's modal realism from other philosophical accounts of possible worlds?
correct_answer: Lewis held that all possible worlds are concrete, spatiotemporally real entities of the same kind as our actual world
distractors: Lewis held that all possible worlds are abstract, mathematical constructions existing only within formal logical systems
Lewis held that all possible worlds are mental, subjective representations existing only within conscious human minds
Lewis held that all possible worlds are linguistic, fictional descriptions existing only within coherent narrative frameworks

question_text: Which philosopher introduced the concept of possible worlds to argue that God actualized 'the best of all possible worlds'?
correct_answer: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, in his 1710 work Theodicy
distractors: Baruch Spinoza, in his 1677 work Ethics Demonstrated in Geometric Order
Immanuel Kant, in his 1781 work Critique of Pure Reason
René Descartes, in his 1641 work Meditations on First Philosophy

question_text: In Cartesian substance dualism, what are the two fundamentally distinct kinds of substance, and what is each defined by?
correct_answer: Mind, defined by thinking (res cogitans), and body, defined by spatial extension (res extensa)
distractors: Form, defined by rational structure (res formalis), and matter, defined by sensory quality (res sensibilis)
Soul, defined by divine origin (res divina), and flesh, defined by biological function (res corporalis)
Spirit, defined by moral agency (res moralis), and nature, defined by causal necessity (res naturalis)
